Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Acquistion of Microwave Network Analyzer for Studies of Global Statistics of Waves in Random Media
Award.AbstractNarration:
0958772
Genack
CUNY Queens College

Technical Summary:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

The N5242A Microwave Network Analyzer from Agilent Technologies will provide the speed and dynamic range needed to collect massive sets of high-quality microwave data on wave propagation in random systems that will dramatically advance this field. Measurements of the transmission coefficients between a large number of points on the input and output of random sample configurations will allow us to determine the matrices for transmission through random samples and to determine their eigenvalues and eigenstates. This will provide the links between the statistics of field, intensity, total transmission, and transmittance and will thereby bridge the gap between optical transmission and electronic conductance. Among the eigenstates of the transmission matrix for opaque media are states with transmission approaching unity. We will find these states and will thereby be able to probe the interior of random systems. We will also be able to determine the eigenvalues of the underlying electromagnetic quasi-normal modes and their speckle patterns in transmission. This will provide a full description of static and dynamic wave properties and will foster advances in imaging and photonics. The success of this work will strengthen the CUNY Photonic Center established to enhance the technological base of the New York City metropolitan area. Students from local high schools and undergraduates as well as graduate students and a postdoc will utilize this equipment to conduct research at the forefront of the field of transport. This will expose a diverse group of students to the excitement and power of research at an early stage of their careers.

Layman Summary:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

We explore and control our environment and stay in touch with one another via waves. In addition to light and sound, we rely increasingly on electron waves and microwave radiation for communication. The shared wave character of light and electrons is behind the rapid growth of the photonics industry and the promise it holds for continued device miniaturization and increased speed. At the same time, the transport of multiply scattered quantum and classical waves in disordered systems remains a crucial issue in communications and imaging. Important examples of propagation in random media are electron flow in conductors and insulators, light scattering in paint, the atmosphere and biological tissue, and acoustic scattering in the earth's crust. The use of the proposed advance microwave measurement system will allow us to decompose the measured microwave field into the fundamental modes of oscillation of waves of randomly scattering systems. This will provide a full description of the transmission of steady-state and pulsed radiation. We will also find ways to combine incident fields to achieve high transmission through opaque systems. This work will advance the understanding of wave scattering and find applications in electronics, medical imaging, and geological exploration for oil and gas. The availability of the advanced microwave source and detector will strengthen the Photonic Center of the City University of New York established to enhance the technological base of the New York City metropolitan area. Students from local high schools and undergraduates as well as graduate students and a postdoc will utilize this equipment to conduct research at the forefront of the field of transport. This will expose a diverse group of students to the excitement of research at an early stage of their careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using the microwave vector network analyzer purchased with the support of this Major Research Instrumentation grant, we have been able to make the first complete measurements of the transmission matrix of waves propagating through disordered systems. This allowed us to find the natural channels of transmission through the random system. The highest transmission channel is near unity even in samples in which scattering is so strong that only a small fraction of the wave energy is transmitted on average.

 We are also able to utilize the transmission matrix to focus radiation through strongly scattering samples. We find the ideal conditions for focusing transmitted waves and determine the contrast between the intensity at the focus point and the background in terms of the effective number of transmission channels participating in transmission. These results are confirmed in microwaves measurements and provide the parameters for optimal focusing and the limits of imaging. A comparison of calculated profileof focused intensity and measured results for both freely diffusing waves and for waves trapped or localized within the medium waves are shown in the figure. Greater contrast is found for freely diffusing waves than for strongly trapped localized waves because in the former case there are many independent transmission channels that can be added together at the focus spot to give a high value of focused intensity.

 We have also found the nature of transport in individual random samples and shown that this is simply given in terms of the effective number of transmission channels. This has allowed us to make a direct connection between statistical aspects of transmitted intensity and of the average of intensity for all channels. These results provide a comprehensive picture of wave propagation in the presence of disorder. The results apply to any type of wave and include light, microwave radiation, acoustic waves, and electron and atom waves.

Aspects of this work are the basis of the research of three Ph.D. students and one postdoctoral fellow supported by an NSF-DMR grant. Two articles have been published and two have been submitted for publication. The demonstration of strong transmission through strongly scattering media holds promise for applications in efficient transmission, surveillance and imaging. The published articles are:

  “Transmission Eigenvalues and the Bare Conductance in the Crossover to Anderson Localization,” Z. Shi and A. Z. Genack, Phys. Rev. Lett. 108, 043901 (2012).

 “Focusing through random media: eigenchannel participation number and intensity correlation,” M. Davy, Z. Shi and A. Z. Genack, Phys. Rev. B 85, 035105 (2012). 

“Subensembles of transmission matrices: The link between statistical optics and mesoscopic conductance,” Matthieu Davy, Zhou Shi, Jing Wang, and Azriel Z. Genack, submitted.

“Wave propagation and localization via quasi-normal modes and transmission eigenchannels,” J. Wang, Z. Shi, M. Davy and A. Z. Genack, submitted to Jour. Mod. Phys.: Conference Series.

 Other products that have resulted from the award are listed below:

 We have collected data of the transmission matrix on several hundred samples of different lengths and at different frequencies. This data will be the basis of several upcoming publications. We also developed the software to find the singular values of the transmission matrix.
